channel.title: Huge PHP tutorial series
channel.description:
Hello there MoparScape. I've decided it's about time I actually contributed to the community. So I thought how better to contribute than to write some tutorials. Unlike a lot of you, I don't care that much for Java, I'm more of a website guy. So instead of this being a java tutorial, I'll write them all on PHP, my specialist language. I've been programming PHP for around 3 or 4 years now, so I'm not exactly a beginner. I'll write all of these tutorials for beginners to follow. They will be written over the course of the next 10-14 days and I'll try and release a tutorial every day. There will be between 9-12 tutorials depending on what I include and the first one will be released today, June 19th. Below you will find an index of what to expect. [center][b][iurl=#Lesson1]Lesson 1 [/iurl]- [/b][/center]Lesson one will contain an introduction to PHP and the use of echoes. Then I will go on to cover variables and their uses. [center][b]Lesson 2 - [/b][/center]Lesson two will be centered around statements and will include; If/if else statements, comparison operators, less than/greater than, switch statements, logical operators and boolean values. [center][b]Lesson 3 - [/b][/center]Lesson three will be centered around functions and will include; variable scope and functions, functions and arguments, getting values out of functions, by ref by val, server variables and the use of some common functions. [center][b]Lesson 4 - [/b][/center]Lesson four will be centered around loops and will include; for loops, while loops, do while loops and the break statement. [center][b]Lesson 5 - [/b][/center]Lesson five will be centered around arrays and will include; setting up an array, getting the values stored in arrays, using text as keys, arrays and for each, sorting array values and random keys from arrays. [center][b]Lesson 6 - [/b][/center]Lesson six will be centered around sessions and cookies and will include; the use of sessions, an explanation of sessions, the use of cookies, an explanation of cookies and the pros and cons between the two of them. [center][b]Lesson 7 - [/b][/center]Lesson seven will be centered around string manipulation and will include; changing case, trimming white space, shuffle characters, finding string positions using strpos, splitting a line of text, joining text into a single line, escaping and a string function list. [center][b]Lesson 8 - [/b][/center]Lesson eight will be centered around the use of PHP in HTML Forms and will include; The HTML form, the method, post and action attributes, the submit button, getting values from a text box, checking if the submit button was clicked, how to keep data the user entered, using radio buttons and using checkboxes. [center][b]Lesson 9 - [/b][/center]Lesson nine will be centered around the security issues you may encounter and will include; the security issues and form elements, htmlspecialchars() and strip_tags(). [center][b]Lesson 10 - [/b][/center]Lesson ten will be centered around working with files in php and will include; opening a file with the readfile function, opening a file with fopen(), options for fopen(), writing to files working with csv files and reading a text file to an array. [center][b]Lesson 11 - [/b][/center]Lesson eleven will be centered around MySQL and it's uses with PHP and will include; accessing a database using php, reading from an sql database, adding to an sql database, sql injection, creating tables, updating a record, using WHERE to limit the retur and deleting a record. So that's my manifest for these tutorials. If anyone would like me to add in an extra sector to this then please, post below. Once the tutorials are complete, I'll put the links to them in here as well as posting them. Please remember, these are for beginners, so don't start your shit being all up in my grill on how easy it is. I hope someone will learn something from these tutorials. [hr] [center][anchor=Lesson1][b]Lesson 1[/b][/anchor] [/center] Hey guys, so I thought it was about time I started creating the tutorials for this, as found in my index post, this is lesson 1 of my 11 lessons on PHP. I'll recap what this lesson is going to cover; An introduction to PHP. Creating your first PHP page. Variables and their uses. So without further ado, here's the first step of the tutorial! [hr] [center][b]PHP 101 - An introduction to PHP.[/b] [/center] PHP is the abbreviation for [i]Hypertext Pre-Processor[/i]. You may be thinking "but that's then HPP?" Yes, HPP was re-arranged to PHP for a whole manner of reasons that don't matter. PHP is probably the most widely used scripting language on the internet today. With PHP, you can do things like create username and password login pages, check details from a form, create forums, picture galleries, surveys, and a whole lot more. If you've come across a web page that ends in PHP, then this page usually has some programming code to liven up the plain, old HTML. PHP is what's known as a server-sided language. This is because PHP doesn't get executed on your computer, it gets executed on the computer that requested the page. They're then displayed in the browser. Okay, so that's more or less the introduction to PHP, it isn't required that you know all of that information, that's just for people who don't know what it's for. So, moving swiftly on; [center][b]Your first PHP page.[/b] [/center] Okay, so here's how you would go about creating your first page in PHP. First of all, unlike HTML, PHP doesn't show up by just simply clicking the file. With PHP, you either need web space, or a server. If you don't have web space, I suggest you download [url=http://www.wampserver.com/en/download.php]this.[/url] Okay, so hopefully now you have downloaded and installed wampserver. This basically creates a server on your PC, so you can now test your scripts. So, if the download and installation worked correctly, you'll now have a new icon in your tray, next to the clock. You can control your server from here, stop it, start it, whatever. You now want to click on [b]localhost[/b] and a page should appear. Click the link under Tools called phpinfo(). If a page appears showing you all your information associated with PHP, congratulations, you've done it all correctly! [b]Some tips; [/b] When saving your PHP files, save them to the WWW directory. When launching your PHP files, type in the address bar of your browser "http://localhost/SCRIPTNAME.php" your server knows where the www folder is and it doesn't need to be told where the "wamp" folder is. Obviously, replace SCRIPTNAME with your file name. If you have any problems, redo the previous steps. If that doesn't work visit the [url=http://www.wampserver.com/phorum/]wampserver forums[/url]. [b][center]So now, on to actually writing a script! [/center][/b] What you want to do is create a new file named [b]test.php[/b] and place it in your WWW directory of wamp. We're going to create a file that displays the text "Hello there, moparians!" First step - open up test.php in your preferred text editor. Second step - making it display the text. So, whenever you're trying to display PHP code, you need to tell the browser you're using PHP coding at this point. You do this by the use of the [/b] so now your whole code will look like this: [code] [/code] Save the file, then open it in your browser by typing "http://localhost/test.php" this should now bring up a page that says - Hello there, Moparians! If it doesn't, you've not completed all of the steps, go back and read over it. Otherwise, congratulations, you've just created your first PHP script! [hr] [b][center]So now on to the next part of the tutorial; [/center][/b] In this section of the tutorial, we're going to work on [b]Variables[/b]. For those of you who don't know what a variable is, a variable is more or less a storage point. You put code into these to use and manipulate throughout your code, these can store both numbers and text. Here's how you'd go about storing a number in a PHP Variable; In PHP, variables are defined by a dollar sign "$" so i'll show you what the variable code should look like and then I'll talk you through it. [code] [/code] So, what the above code is doing. at $moparscape, it's defining the variable moparscape. So that anywhere in your code that you type $moparscape, the code is going to see it as the value on the right of your equals sign. Also, I should've said this earlier, but I'm saying it now, end your php coding lines with a semicolon "[b];[/b]" unless instructed otherwise, or you know it's wrong. Back to explaining the code; Then after the variable of moparscape has been assigned the value of 10, we want to test our variable. So, remember the echo function we tried out before this? We use that again. We echo the variable $moparscape, this being assigned the value of 10 means the browser reads it as 10, understand? Congratulations, you've just created your first variable! Obviously, this isn't the only variable in PHP, this is only for assigning numbers to. I'll now show you how to assign text to a variable. So, what you want to do is most of the above, but the difference here is that instead of just doing > [code] $moparscape = the best community ever!; [/code] We're going to wrap the text we want to be assigned to the $moparscape variable in speech marks - " ". So it'd look like; [code] $moparscape = "the best community ever!"; [/code] So now, your whole code will look like; [code] [/code] So there you go, you can now assign both text and numbers to variables in PHP, congratulations! Until tomorrow, I suggest you mess around with your variables and practise them by doing stuff like this; [code] "; echo "What would you rate $community?"; echo "
"; echo "I'd rate it $rate!"; ?> [/code] So now, you can screw around with variables until tomorrow, when I release my second lesson which is slightly more advanced with statements, take a look at my index found above for more information on my lessons. Now, that's all I'm going to speak about today, hang in there until tomorrow! [hr]

item.title: Huge PHP tutorial series
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:6, topic:445929”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=548780.msg4029523#msg4029523 date=1340626546]

If PHP sucked it wouldn’t be used in such a large scale.
Just your opinion, is all.

The popularity of a language is not proportionate to its shittiness.
At all.

Are you still wanting to join the Xythax development team?
[/quote]

I’d like to, but I’m going on vacation soon and I don’t think that I’d be able to hold up with the commitment.[/quote]

Okay, well when you get back, feel free to PM me your application, you seem like one of the few good programmers on this forum.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:3, topic:445929”]PHP is a shit language.
I’d suggest reading this article to find out more.
Pretty much any language can be used as a server sided programming language - Clojure with the Noir framework, Haskell with the Snap framework, Java or Scala with the Play framework, or something like RoR or Django. PHP isn’t your only choice for server sided programming.[/quote]

PHP does suck as a language, but I always feel better reading this article,

ircmaxell's Blog

PHP Sucks! But I Like It!

I read a rather interesting post yesterday called PHP: a fractal of bad design. It’s been getting a lot of traffic among the PHP community lately because it’s rather inflammatory. But to be honest, it

Read full topic

item.title: Huge PHP tutorial series
item.dc:creator: @xxOrpheus xxOrpheus
item.description:
@xxOrpheus wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:24, topic:445916”][quote author=ravekitty link=topic=548780.msg4027472#msg4027472 date=1340466745]

don’t listen to anything this guy says.
he said including files instead of hardcoding them makes your site load faster.

For all I know…
He’s the best php/website developer I know.

also.
WHEN ARE YOU RELEASING LESSON 2.?!??@?!@?!@ ;p
[/quote]

Okay, so it’s been a while since I released a tutorial, and I realise some of the other stuff I released was a little advanced for a lot of you to understand, so here’s something I use very, very often. This shortens the file size by a fuck load and you can use it to make your pages load at an unbelievably faster rate.

So lets get to work.

I’ll guarantee that all of the top of your HTML pages will look like this:

<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
<head>
  <title>SITETITLE</title>
  <meta name="description" content="website description" />
  <meta name="keywords" content="website keywords, website keywords" />
  <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=windows-1252" />
  <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cssfile" />
</head>
<body>
      <div id="logo">
		<img src="style/logo.png">
      </div>
      <div id="menubar">
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
	  <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
        </ul>
      </div>

Now, typically, that is a good 1/4 of your website code right there.
How would you feel if I told you that you could put that all in one line?

Pretty awesome, I know.

This can all be shortened down to;

<?php include('header.inc') ?>

How do you do this? Well just read on.

Copy and paste your header code into a file named “header.inc” and then simply replace the code you pasted into header.inc with the above php code.
PLEASE NOTE: Remember to change your file to .php instead of .html

You can also do this for your footer, this will replace A LOT of your coding, [size=24pt]thus making your web page load a hell of a lot faster. Even noobs to website development can do this.[/size]

Enjoy.

Lol^.[/quote]

case closed, bring in the dancing lobsters.
for all you know, i’m the best php dev. you don’t know.

Read full topic

This shortens the file size by a fuck load and you can use it to make your pages load at an unbelievably faster rate.

So lets get to work.

I’ll guarantee that all of the top of your HTML pages will look like this:

		<img src="style/logo.png">
      </div>
      <div id="menubar">
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
	  <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
          <li><a href="#">LINK</a></li>
        </ul>
      </div>

Now, typically, that is a good 1/4 of your website code right there.
How would you feel if I told you that you could put that all in one line?

Pretty awesome, I know.

This can all be shortened down to;

<?php include('header.inc') ?>

How do you do this? Well just read on.

Copy and paste your header code into a file named “header.inc” and then simply replace the code you pasted into header.inc with the above php code.
PLEASE NOTE: Remember to change your file to .php instead of .html

You can also do this for your footer, this will replace A LOT of your coding, [size=24pt]thus making your web page load a hell of a lot faster. Even noobs to website development can do this.[/size]

Enjoy.[/quote]

Lol^.

item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:12, topic:445916”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=548780.msg4023113#msg4023113 date=1340152498]

Mmm I’m not sure how I feel about deleting peoples posts so that they conform. How many will fit into the OP? Try to do that first, and then add onto your other posts. Then I’ll ask the people if they don’t mind their posts getting removed so that you can have the double post.

I’m guessing two at most will fit into the OP. I’d need like 5 posts to fit everything I’ve got planned I reckon.
[/quote]

I suggest using BBC anchors if you have multiple tutorials in one posts
Usage

[iurl=#Example1]Example[/iurl] [anchor=Example1]Example[/anchor]

[iurl=#Example1]Example[/iurl]

[anchor=Example1]Example[/anchor][/quote]
